title: about
text: Hard work can be draining, so I value the time I can get outdoors. I am privileged to live by the ocean and travel to other beautiful places for work. I try to make the most of this by finding quiet time to myself, whether it be on a surfboard or on a walk with my pup. When I can’t hear the birds, that’s when I know it’s time to hike somewhere and sleep outside for a few days.

title: Jacey C. Van Wert
text:
hello!

I’m Jacey. I’m a PhD candidate at UC Santa Barbara in the Eliason Lab. If I’m not at my desk or in the field, you’ll typically find me in the water or in the sand with my pup.

title: research
text:
In short, I assess the vulnerability of various species of Pacific salmon to changing river conditions (warm waters, various flow rates) to protect and conserve this threatened species. In collaboration with various stakeholders, I use a variety of techniques including blood physiology, enzyme and metabolite metrics, histology, respirometry, and tagging and tracking.





Sockeye salmon radio-tagged on the Fraser River. PC: Kim Birnie-Gauvin

title: about
text: land meets sea

title: research
section: Consequences of a marine heatwave on the performance of coral reef fish
text: Consequences of a marine heatwave on the performance of coral reef fish

title: research
text:
Coral reef fish
On the other side of the equator and in very different clothing, I work with coral reef fish. Coral reef ecosystems are facing extreme temperatures. Corals and reef fish are both particularly near the edge of their thermal limits, threatening the health of coral reef ecosystems. The goal of these studies are to better understand the importance of fish in coral reefs and their plastic responses to marine heatwaves. I use nutrient analyses, respirometry, behavioral surveys, and cardiac thermal tolerance tests.





Observing fish on the forereef in Moorea, French Polynesia.

title: research
text:
Fisheries
I recently was awarded funding by NSF to work with NOAA Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center to assess various management strategies on incidental by-catch of protected species. More to come!





Fishing vessel. PC: Ocean Image Bank, Nicolas Jab

title: land and sea
text:
There is no easy way to acknowledge those who have been oppressed by my actions or inactions. I hope to demonstrate my sincerity and gratitude despite this virtual platform. As a scholar and European descendant, I have benefited from the systemic oppression, exclusion, and erasures of Indigenous peoples across North American lands. I am located in central coastal California and work and live on the unceded ancestral lands and waters of the Chumash people. I am grateful for the generations of Chumash people who have stewarded these lands and waters that I use today for life, work, and recreation. I am committed to continue learning about the systemic oppression and work towards a more equitable system. I aim to promote the work of oppressed voices and collaborate across community members and stakeholders, with the shared goals to conserve our natural resources. I invite all feedback and remain open minded as I develop into the scientist that I want to be.
An important first step is for us to understand the Native Land and history in which we work and live. This interactive map may be useful to you.

title: about
text:
land and sea

I am grateful for the land that I work on, live on, and visit.
There is no easy way to acknowledge those who have been oppressed by my actions or inactions. On a virtual platform, it is further challenging to demonstrate my sincerity and gratitude. As a scholar and European descendant, I have benefited from the systemic oppression, exclusion, and erasures of Indigenous peoples across North American lands. I am located in central coastal California and work and live on the unceded ancestral lands and waters of the Chumash people. I am grateful for the generations of Chumash people who have stewarded these lands and waters that I use today for life, work, and recreation. I am committed to continue learning about the systemic oppression and work towards a more equitable system. With my work as a scientist, I hope to restore and conserve our natural resources.
An important first step is for us to understand the Native Land and history in which we work and live. This interactive map may be useful: https://native-land.ca/

title: about
text:
intro to science Microscope
Like most people, my path to present day is nonlinear. It started off with a childhood in the woods and backyard, a yearning for sunshine and warmth, and a few dedicated teachers at Santa Barbara City College. During my CC days, I had my first research experience at UC Santa Barbara studying raccoon parasites with at the time, graduate student Sara Weinstein. I loved the process of science and wanted more, and was awarded an NSF REU at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole. I worked with Dr. Allen Mensinger on toadfish bioacoustics. At the time, I had no idea fish vocalized! I spent several additional summmers studying toadfish neurophysiology and was hooked to physiology.
I wanted to merge my scientific background with my desire to learn and conserve vulnerable systems. That brings me to today, my final year or so as a PhD candidate at UC Santa Barbara in Dr. Erika Eliasons’ lab.

my intro to science Tree Sun Microscope
Like most people, my path to present day is nonlinear. It started off with a childhood in the woods and backyard, a yearning for sunshine and warmth, and a few dedicated teachers at Santa Barbara City College. During my CC days, I had my first research experience at UC Santa Barbara studying raccoon parasites with at the time, graduate student Sara Weinstein. I loved the process of science and wanted more, and was awarded an NSF REU at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole. I worked with Dr. Allen Mensinger on toadfish bioacoustics. At the time, I had no idea fish vocalized! I spent several additional summmers studying toadfish neurophysiology and was hooked to physiology.
That brings me to today, my final year or so at UC Santa Barbara in Erika Eliaosn’s lab.

title: PhD metrics
text:
world <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")
collabs <- read.csv(here("phd-metrics", "map", "collabs-coordinates.csv"))

collabs_maps <- ggplot() +
    geom_sf(data = world, color = "black", fill = "snow1")+
  coord_sf(xlim= c(-180, 180), ylim = c(-50, 80))+
    geom_point(data = collabs, aes(y = lat, x = long, size = Count), color = "orchid4", alpha = .6)+
    ggtitle("PhD Collaborations")+
  scale_size(range=c(3, 5), breaks=c(1, 5, 10, 15))+
    theme_map()

ggsave(here("phd-metrics", "map", "map_collabs.png"))

Saving 7 x 5 in image

title: PhD metrics
text:
Presentations

pres <- read.csv(here("phd-metrics", "plots", "presentations.csv"))

pres_count <- pres %>%
  dplyr::count(presentation_type)%>%
  filter(n<100)

x<-ggplot(pres_count, aes(x = presentation_type, y = n))+
  geom_col(fill = "orchid4")+
  labs(y = "Number", x = "\nPresentation type")+
  ggtitle("Presentations throughout PhD")+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(0, 5, 10))+
  theme(
  panel.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent",
                                  colour = NA_character_), # necessary to avoid drawing panel outline
  panel.grid.major = element_blank(), # get rid of major grid
  panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), # get rid of minor grid
  plot.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent",
                                 colour = NA_character_), # necessary to avoid drawing plot outline
  legend.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent"),
  legend.box.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent"),
  legend.key = element_rect(fill = "transparent"))+
  theme(text=element_text(size=20), #change font size of all text
        axis.text=element_text(size=20), #change font size of axis text
        axis.title=element_text(size=20), #change font size of axis titles
        plot.title=element_text(size=28), #change font size of plot title
        legend.text=element_text(size=20), #change font size of legend text
        legend.title=element_text(size=20)) #change font size of legend title   

ggsave(here("phd-metrics", "plots", "presentations.png"), width = 18, height = 10)

title: community
text:
dissemination
What is knowledge if it isn’t shared? Not only do I care about sharing my scientific findings, but it is important to share my experiences. Below are some ways I’ve shared my scientific journey, perspective, and science throughout my PhD.

title: community
text:
collaborations
I’ve been fortunate to have worked with brilliant minds from across the globe. I value each and everyone’s perspective that has been influential to my career and personal development.







dissemination
What is knowledge if it isn’t shared? Not only do I care about sharing my scientific findings, but it is important to share my experiences. Below are some ways I’ve shared my scientific journey, perspective, and science throughout my PhD.
